column2: Ajahn Pasanno describes mindfulness of breathing as a method to firmly establish the mind and develop insight.

I notice a connection between a person who is preparing for transition and going though agonal breathing. It's one breath per minute or two, and it's relaxed.
You have to keep letting go until there is no remainder.|Ajahn Chah
I've had the experience on retreat of getting to slow, shallow breathing and panicked because I couldn't find the breath. Could you say more about just going to the knowing?
I have a hard time breathing normally due to congestion and athsma. How does one get past the initial fear, 'I just can't breathe. How am I going to do this?'
At what point in your meditation do you shift to knower or witness?
At times during my meditation, my body acts funny, leaning to one side or the other or spinning. What causes this? Is it a good or bad sign?
When I practice mindfulness of breathing, thought arises. Do I want to eliminate thinking?
My mind will fill with chatter, stuff I'm not interested in. What I've come to do is just say, 'This is a chaotic mind.'
How do you keep the self from coming up if this is an interesting thought to follow?
Sometimes there will be sponaneous verbal recollection of Dhamma. Is this skillful?
I get stuck with subtle unpleasant moods. Any advice?
Could you translate sati as recognizing?
Dispassion, fading away—these things are happening anyway, and we're learning to see them.
I tend to make things harder for myself. I come up with some big projections.
[Question unclear] Is modulating a good way to describe working with the breath?
My mind goes away, and I'm lost in a story. But if I sit and don't move, eventually when I come back I realize the body is really settled and I can tune in to that.
Modulating the breath seems more sublte than controlling it. Does this relate to where you put your attention as it grows?
How often do you employ mindfulness of breathing in daily life? How much volition are you still using?
How can we balance happiness and ease with the desire to accomplish something using meditation techniques?
Sometimes I've been sitting a long time and am too tired to keep sitting, walk, or stand. Any suggestions?
When you contemplate, 'Who is thinking? Who is breathing?' how does this differ from thinking? Why doesn't it generate more thought?
The mind can still think and be peaceful. What a concept!
